metadata.title: Options Rho Calculator (Black-Scholes, European)
metadata.description: Compute the Rho (sensitivity of an option price to the risk-free interest rate) for European call and put options using the Black‑Scholes model. Includes option price and rho per unit and per 1% change in interest rate, with guidance on assumptions, calibration and limitations.

introduction: This calculator computes the Rho of a European option under the Black‑Scholes framework. Rho is the partial derivative of the option price with respect to the continuously compounded risk‑free interest rate and expresses how the option price changes when rates move.

The tool returns the Black‑Scholes call price and both call and put Rho values expressed per unit change in the annual rate (i.e. per 1.0 = 100 percentage points) and per one percentage point change (multiply per unit by 0.01). Use inputs for underlying price, strike, days to expiry, annual volatility, risk‑free rate and dividend yield.
methodology: Calculations use the Black‑Scholes closed‑form expressions for European options. Key assumptions: lognormal asset returns, constant volatility and interest rates, continuous dividend yield, and European exercise (no early exercise).

Rho is calculated analytically from the Black‑Scholes formula: for a call C, rho = ∂C/∂r = K * T * exp(-rT) * N(d2). For a put P, rho = ∂P/∂r = -K * T * exp(-rT) * N(-d2). The calculator exposes both the per‑unit and per‑one‑percentage‑point versions.
how_is_calculated: Time to expiry T is days / 365.
Convert percentage inputs to decimals where needed: volatility σ = volatility(%) / 100; r = risk‑free rate(%) / 100; q = dividend yield(%) / 100.
d1 = (ln(S/K) + (r - q + 0.5 * σ^2) * T) / (σ * sqrt(T)). d2 = d1 - σ * sqrt(T).
Call price C = S * e^{-qT} * N(d1) - K * e^{-rT} * N(d2).
Call Rho (per unit of r) = K * T * e^{-rT} * N(d2). Put Rho (per unit of r) = -K * T * e^{-rT} * N(-d2). Rho per 1 percentage point = Rho_per_unit * 0.01.

faqs.question: Is this Rho valid for American options or options on futures?
faqs.answer: No. The formula implemented is the Black‑Scholes closed form for European options on underlying assets with continuous dividend yield. American options and certain futures options require different models (binomial, finite difference, or Black 76). Use models appropriate to exercise style and underlying.

faqs.question: What are the main limitations of the Black‑Scholes Rho?
faqs.answer: It assumes constant volatility and interest rates and no early exercise; Rho reflects sensitivity for small instantaneous changes in the risk‑free rate under those assumptions. Large rate moves, stochastic rates, discrete dividends, or volatility skew will make results approximate.

faqs.question: How should I interpret Rho per percentage point versus per unit?
faqs.answer: Rho per unit is the derivative ∂price/∂r when r is expressed as a decimal (e.g., change per 1.0 = 100 percentage points). Rho per 1 percentage point multiplies that derivative by 0.01 and shows the expected price change for a 1 percentage‑point (100 basis points) change in the annual rate.

faqs.question: How can I improve accuracy for traded instruments?
faqs.answer: Calibrate implied volatility from market option prices for matching strike and tenor, use market yields for the risk‑free curve and account for discrete dividends if material. Consider Monte Carlo or local volatility models when path‑dependent or early exercise features are present.

faqs.question: Are results guaranteed to be exact?
faqs.answer: No. Results are mathematically correct under Black‑Scholes assumptions but subject to input quality, numerical precision, and model limitations. See accuracy and compliance notes below.

glossary.definition: Sensitivity of the option price to a small change in the risk‑free interest rate, mathematically ∂Price/∂r.
Auxiliary variables in Black‑Scholes used in the closed‑form pricing expressions; functions of S, K, r, q, σ and T.
The volatility value which, when plugged into a pricing model, reproduces a market option price.
